instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2879: What is 820-2879? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SYS_ONEWIRE: What is SYS_ONEWIRE? This is a bidirectional communication line between the system management controller(SMC) and the charger that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC. This must be working for the light to come on on the magsafe charger. .
definitions.ADAPTER_SENSE: What is ADAPTER_SENSE? This is a line between the onewire circuit and the magsafe charger where the magsafe charger can talk to the SMC(system management controller) on the SYS_ONEWIRE line..
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK_VCC: What is SMC_BC_ACOK_VCC? SMC_BC_ACOK_VCC is a voltage that is created if SMC_BC_ACOK & PP3V42_G3H are both present that powers the chipset for the onewire circuit that allows the SMC to talk to the charger on the SYS_ONEWIRE line. This is necessary for the magsafe charger to have a light on it. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no magsafe
threads.message:
This macbook pro has no magsafe and I found

<CHIP>U6900</CHIP>
<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK_VCC</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>SYS_ONEWIRE</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> - 7.26V

This means bad SMC?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no magsafe
threads.message: Hi, I am new to board repair myself but never heard of the term "no MagSafe". To start diagnosing you need an original Magsafe charger, and a known working DC-IN board. A possible scenario would be: "green light in the charger but no fan spin"

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no magsafe
threads.message: Yes, I mean not green light. PPBUS is 12.56V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no magsafe
threads.message: <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> at 7V means either a bad magsafe board or crap under the connector on the board. Somehow voltage is leaking into it, it should never be over 3.3V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no magsafe
threads.message:
Yes was bad magsafe board. I replaced it and now I have good green light and <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>. 

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - present
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> - missing
No fan spinning.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no magsafe
threads.message: This board does not auto power on, use power pads and see what happen...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no magsafe
threads.message:
Yes, I know that. This is MCP board. Not i5-i7
I short to ground onoff

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no magsafe
threads.message: Resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>, resistance to ground on pins 1 and 4 from Y2810???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no magsafe
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> - 8K

Y2810 20M and infinity.

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - present
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> - missing
No fan spinning.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no magsafe
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no magsafe
threads.message: Are you sure?? Why do you think so?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no magsafe
threads.message: Resistance on PP3V42 is too low, should be about 30-45K, I know this for experience.... But if you want to feel more comfortable, Dukefawks told me this........ That said I hope now that you believe me...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no magsafe
threads.message:
I don't believe you Aprendiz! ;)

Yeah 8K on 3V42 is usually a dead MCP.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no magsafe
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no magsafe
threads.message:
Today it works. I didnot do anything. Still 8K there. So... still suspect MCP?
Will test 1 week.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no magsafe
threads.message: I bet you are measuring with red probe to ground....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no magsafe
threads.message: Red to ground? Why this? In diode mode I measure with red to ground yes. But in normal mode it really matters?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no magsafe
threads.message: find out yourself, do the test in both ways, red to ground and black to ground....
